FacilityName: Morgantown Utility Board Water Treatment Plant

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Water and Sewer Line and Related Structures Construction

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Morgntown Utility Board accidental release prevention program involves established operating procedures and prudent management practices.  Its procedures follow the guidance of the U.S. Environmental protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program.

The Morgantown Utility Board Water Treatment Plant currently serves approximately 23,000 customers and an additional 8 Resale Customers (Public Service Districts, Water Associations, Etc..)  The plant draws most of its water from the Monongahela River and treats approximately 10 gallons of water per day.

The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of two chlorine release scenarios, identified as "worst case release" and "alternative release scenario."  The first scenario is defined by the EPA, which states that "the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quanitity in the largest vesselA?is released as a gas over 10 minutes," due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario."

The "worst case release scenario" involves two nearly empty one ton cylinders (less than 500 lbs each) that are each respectively manifolded to full one ton cylinders when an accident occurs, causing all four cylinders to release their contents.  This maximum quantity of 5000 lbs is ensured by strict adherence to the practice of connecting a full cylinder to the manifolds only after the corresponding active cylinder contents has been depleted to 500 lbs or less.

The "alternative release scenario" involves a single one ton cylinder having an automatic shut-off valve failure combined with a line breakage.  The RMP Comp program was used to define the distance to the toxic endpoint.  Additional active mitigation measures taken include replacement of the existing chlorinators to a remote vacuum type, with all pressurized chlorine piping replaced with vacuum piping.  This will further reduce the amount of chlorine released in case of piping rupture.

The

general Morgantown Utility Board accidental release prevention program is based on the following:

Training of Operators
Preventive maintenance program
Use state-of-the-art process and safety equipment
Use of effective operating procedures

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, and the presence of chlorine detectors.

No accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at this facility in the past five years.

The facility has an emergency response program, which has been coordinated (reviewed) by MECCA, which is a member of the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

For the RMP Submittal, any unanswered are either "Not Applicable" or no information available.
